Face surveillance misidentified 1 in 6 New England athletes.
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
Take Action Now

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

For months now, we've been reading about face surveillance – that it's dangerous and unreliable – but we wanted to see for ourselves.

Last month, the ACLU ran a little experiment. Using a widely available face recognition tool, we compared the official photos of famous New England athletes with a mugshot database. The software produced 27 false matches – a rate of 1 in 6. Not a good look.

This technology is not ready for primetime. Send a message to state lawmakers: face surveillance threatens all of us, no matter who we are.

If face surveillance can't recognize Gordon Hayward, Chris Sale, or Brad Marchand in a lineup, what hope do the rest of us have? We need to press pause on the government's use of this dystopian technology until we can safeguard our civil liberties.

We can't let the surveillance state win – and we won't. Let lawmakers know that you'll never back down on privacy rights.

In solidarity,

Kade Crockford
Director, Technology for Liberty Project
ACLU of Massachusetts
